document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. document.text: Assassination or Lynching? Acting Secretary Hill dispatched tc the Italian Charge here, Count Carig nani, a copy of the report of Governoi Longino, of Mississippi upon the recen killing of Italians at Erwin. The Governor says that it has no yet been determined whether the Ital ians were naturalized citizens of th United States. After receiving news of the outbreak he immediately senl the sheriff of Washington county, ir which county the affair took place, tc the spot, and on the second day th Governor went. there in person anti learned that every endeavor was mak ing to discover and punish the guilts parties. The residents of Washington county the Governor says, condemn the out rage, and he assures the State Depart ment. and requests that the assuranc be communicated to the Italian Gov ernment. that every proper effort is b? ing made to bring the lynchers to jus tice. A study of the Governors repor makes it appear that after all the ques tion of the nationality of the murderec Italians will not be the principal issu in the inquiry. The Governor appar ently leans strongly to the belief tha- there was no real lynching but tha- the affair was a simple assassin? oi and that the men were not killed be cause they-were Italians, but as the re suit of a tribal quarrel. Should thi view be surtained by the inqu ry now i progress, the case at once will lose i international aspect. To Retire ia February. Rear-Admiral W. T. Sampson wil go on the retired list in February next when he will be relieved of command of the Boston Navy Yard by Rear Admiral M. L. Johnson. In case Rear-Admiral Sampson should like to be unattached, as is Rear-Ad miral Schley, in order that he may at tend the session of the court of inquirv he will be immediately detached frorr  his present duty and placed on waiting orders. No intimalion has reached th I department that Rear-Admiral Samp son would like immediate detachment but the Secretary is disposed to gran- a request for relief from his presen1 duty in case the officer should submil it. _______ Clerks and Their Superiors. The fact that certain clerks to quar j termasters and commissary officers ob I jected to accompanying those officer I when transferred to other stations ha?  induced the acting Secretary of War tc i issue the following notice to all con j cerned The Secretary of War consid  ers- that the interests of the service re I quire that employees at large in the de ! partment must be subject to orders it j regard to transfer of station, and a re fusal to obey such orders will be deemec a proper and sufficient reason for dis ! charge from the service.

Clark, 24 Dan iel Knowles, 13, George Tice, 40. The new Episcopal Church at Min eral will be completed within the next 10 days. Rev. M. S. Eagle is the rector. Capt. T. C. Morton is canvassing Richmond, for the balance of the 10,- 000 needed to reproduce Monticello at the St. Louis Exposition. Mecklenburg county Democrats have nominated E. C. Goode for Common wealths Attorney B. E. Cogbill, Treasurer W. R. Beals, Sheriff Com missioner of the Revenue in District No. 1, T. F. Pectus, and in District No. 2, J. S. Montgomery S. P. Reed, for the House of Delegates. Staunton Daughters of the Confed eracy have elected the following dele gates to the Norfolk meeting Mes- dames Carter Harrison, McCullough, J. E. B. Stuart and Miss Minnie Mor ton alternates, Mesdames Nelms, Bis- sel and Tnrk and Miss Margaret Tim- berlake. At Charlottesville lociil physicians and surgeons have organized a stock com pany to erect a private sanitarium. The promoters are Drs. J. Hamilton Browning, Charles S. Venable, Hugh T. Nelson, William M. Randolph, W. Douglas Macon, Edward M. Magru- der and Halstead S. Hedges. The Virginia Medical Society at its closing session at Roanoke decided that in the future physicians may place business cards and advertisements of private hospitals in newspapers. Df. B. C. Keister, charged with advertis ing, in violation of the code of ethics, was, however, criticised by the society. Richmond was chosen as the next place of meeting. A deed has been recorded in the County Clerks office in Staunton con veyin g all of the property of the Cri- mora Manganese Company, of V ir ginia, to the Crimora Manganese Com pany, of New Jersey. This property is assessed at 30,000, but it is worth sev eral times that amount.  Gus Pryor, a negro, was arrested in Winchester charged with horse steal ing. It is alleged he stole a horse from James Slonaker, at Capon Bridge, a week ago. Grover Henry, the 19-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Henry, was killed by a freight train on the Norfolk and Western Railroad at Bentonville, W ar ren county. Young Henry was walking toward his home on the main track when he was struck. Mrs. Flemming, wife of Capt. J. H. Flemming, repulsed a negro who at tacked her when on her way home from a neighbors in the Park View suburb of Norfolk. The highwayman caught Mrs. Flemming by the arm and throat and demanded her money and jewelry. She gave him a stunning blow in the face with her fist, which so startled the negro that he fled. The tidewater truckers, with Mr. Henry Kirn as president, held a secret meeting in Norfolk, the purpose of which is to inaugurate a line of steamships be tween that city and New York. The wealthy trucker are dissatisfied with the rates and facilities of the Old Dominion Steamship Company. The Supreme Court of Appeals, in an opinion handed down at Staunton, de clared unconstitutional the act passed bj the Virginia Legislature several years ago prohibiting the use of trading stamps. The lower court is reversed ir the case, which went up from Berryville, and under the decision merchants maj resume the giving of stamps to custom ers. The use of the frading. stamps hac become popular in Richmond, Norfolk and other cities a few years ago when under the pressure of mercantile in fluence, the Legislature passed an ac forbidding their use. Mrs. E. R. Shenk and daughter, Mis Effie Shenk, of White Post, had a thril ling escape from drowning while cross ing the Opequon on the Millwood road on their way to Winchester. The Ope quon was swollen, and when in mid stream their buggy overturned. Mis Shenk was swept beneath the vehicle but after a terrible battle both ladies managed to reach the opposite bank. Tht horse swam out, but the buggy war smashed. Jas. Pritchard, aged 23 years, a son of Postmaster C. W. Pritchard, of Shenan doah, was run over by a Norfolk and Western train at Berryville and instantly killed. It is believed that Pritchard fell between the cars while stealing a ride. W. D. Bowles, the mail clerk who is charged with robbing the United States mail, was indicted by the grand jury in thd United States Court at Lynchburg. He was admitted to bail in i,coo, .with his brothers, J. C. and Malcolm S. Bowles, as his sureties. Mr. H. Eugene Ritter and Miss A. Blanche Weakley, of Winchester, were married Friday. The bride is barely 15 years of age and was attired in short skirts.. She is a daughter of Benjamin F. Weakley, who gave his.consent to the marriage. Rural Free-Delivery Inspector James S. Walbach had a close call at Wertz. He was at a country postoffice investi gating a complaint against a letter car rier. There was a large oil lamp burn ing over the place where the investiga tors were sitting and underneath was a loaded revolver. Having completed the examination Mr. Walbach walked to the door, when he declare the lamp exploded and the revolver was discharged. The large Bartycs Mill of the Nulsen- Krausse Manufacturing Company was destroyed by fire at Lynchburg. This was the largest of the companys thre mills, two of which are in Lynchburg The loss is about 25,000, with some in surance. The Thirteenth Tennessee Cavalry o Federal Veterans, to whose credit i placed the killing of General Morgan ai Grecneville, will hold its eighth annua reunion at Neva, Johnson county, Tenn. next month. The reunion will last threr days, the dates being October 7, 8 and 9 The veterans will camp in the moun tains. The ladies will participate anc there will be vocal choruses. At Campbell Courthouse, S. C., Gog- gin and John E. Withos. candidates fot nomination for clerk of the Court o Campbell County, tried to engage in a joint discussion, but the discussion end ed in a general row.

He then told of deeds of valor done by the Confi derate soldiers, bow at Antie- tum 35,000 Confederates, who were in a half starved condition, drove back 90,000 Federal soldiers. Every body sings the praise of the Con federates. Deep down in his heart is the love of home and the love of God. He has gone along filling the offices of duty and of destiny, and turning to Mr. E. document.text: President Roosevelt left Washing ton for his holiday vacation at Pine Knot, the Virginia cottage owned by the Roosevelts, near Charlottesville. With him were Mrs. Roosevelt and their five children, also Assistant Secretary M. C. Latta, Surgeon General of the Navy Rixey, Secret Service Agent Jam es Sloan and Miss Landon, of Oyster Bay, a friend of Miss Ethel Roosevelt. Secretary Shaw has issued a cir cular that no surety company shall accepted on bond in which the government is interested for an mount greater than 10 per cent, of Its paid up capital. The Department of Agriculture is determined to have enforced the law prohibiting railroads from confining live stock beyond the 36-hour limit. Sir Mortimer Diirand, the retiring British ambassador, called upon Sec retary Root. The sword of Paul Jones has been deposited in the Library of the Navy Department. Brig. Gen. J. Franklin Bell will be promoted to be a major general. The Supreme Court decided that the succession tax of 7,000 assessed against the board of education of Kentucky Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church is valid. The Supreme Court decided that it has jurisdiction to try Sheriff Shipp and others, of Chattanooga, Tenn., for contempt of court in connection with the lynching of Ed Johnson. The constitutionality of the North Carolina statute forbidding the oper ations of a bucket shop was upheld by the Supreme Court of the United States. Justice Moody, formerly attorney general, has been assigned to the Third Circuit, embracing Pennsylva nia, New Jersey and Delaware. The inheritance tax of Louisiana was declared by the Supreme Court of the United States to be constitu tional. Anton W inter, who made the new counterfeit two doUar certificate, was arrested in Rochester, N. Y. The Enterprise Transportation Company of Jamestown, R. I.. filed complaint with the Interstate Com merce Commission against the Penn sylvania Railroad Company and the New England Navigation Company as to existing transportation rates In his annual report Rear Admiral Rae, chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department, says th at the steam turbine presents one of the greatest problems of the day. Captain Marix, of the Navy, re ported experiments for coaling ves sels at sea to he unsuccessful. Edwin T. Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn., will succeed J. C. McReynolds as an assistant attorney general.  President Roosevelt will spend a portion of the Christmas holidays at Pine Knot, Va.

Walden, a prominent Dem- oerat, by Perry Wallin, a Republican tender, has fanned a smouldering poli tical feud in the Blackwater district to a threatened outbreak. All through the mountain district the clans are pining up. The coming trial of 200 paoonshlners, charged with vote sell ing, is causing the local authorities to paake preparations for the protection Of the court and jury. They fear an Outbreak paralleling the tragedy at HlUsville last March, when, with the exception of one man, the entire hu man fabric of the court was wiped out. Judge Skeen got a message from the mountains reading There are 38 in Our party. Before we will submit to going to jail we will die and go to hell. Newport News.This city over whelmingly voted a bond issue of 26,- 900 to purchase water-front property and construct a small boat harbor and municipal pier. The vote was 160 to 95. In addition to the small boat har bor and piers, the bond issue means Che purchase of 110 acres of land sur rounding the harbor tor factory sites and will give the city 2,000 feet of water front at the junction of James rive and Hampton Roads. The har bor will combine water and rail trans portation. Petersburg.A large brick building I pn Canal street, used as a branch mill f the Virginia Consolidated Milling Company, was entirely destroyed by ftre, with machinery and a large quan- tfty of flour and cornmeal. The loss, trhlch is covered by insurance, will probably be in the neighborhood of 126,000 or 30,000. The fire occurred Curing a heavy electric storm. The building, which was owned by the Vir ginia Railway and Power Company, is supposed to have been struck by light- king. Fredericksburg.The election in Caroline county on the question of issuing 126,000 of county bonds to be used in the construction of permanent good roads resulted in a defeat of the  bond issue by a majority of 164. Many  localities in the county were largely In favor of the bond issue, while other sections were just as firmly opposed The result of the election Is a great disappointment to many in the county j as well as others who regret to see any check to the movement for good roads through the State.  Fredericksburg.The season in this action this summer has been one of the finest known in years and it promises to be a great crop year, showers having fallen at intervals just as needed, and the corn crop never looked better at this date in previous  ears. More hay has been raised than aver before, especially alfalfa, and vegetables and fruits of all kinds are Plentiful and excellent in quality. i . Fredericksburg. Spotsylvania and Hanover al- -ready have good roads.  Winchester.Although Winchester has had no saloons for four years, the Anti-Saloon League will ask for a local-option election to be held early in September. Temperance leaders claim the liquor trust is about to  throw money into Winchester for capi tation taxes, and it is desired to have the issue settled by the ordinary elec torate, which at the lastelection gave the dry ticket 160 majority. He is anxious to correspond with young men from 16 to 21 years of age who may be . qualified. He advises that only per sons who have had high school or t preparatory school training should  apply.
